mythology: The Princess Andromeda; in Greek mythology, the daughter of Cepheus and Cassiopeia and wife of Perseus.
name: Andromeda

mythology: The air pump; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, originally the 'pneumatic machine'.
name: Antlia

mythology: The bird of paradise; a southern constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Apus

mythology: The water bearer; in Greek mythology, Ganymede, wine-waiter to the Gods and lover of Zeus.
name: Aquarius

mythology: The eagle; in Greek mythology, the bird of Zeus and the retriever of his thunderbolts.
name: Aquila

mythology: The altar; in Greek mythology, used by the Gods to vow allegiance before their battle with the Titans.
name: Ara

mythology: The ram; in Greek mythology, the animal whose golden fleece was recovered by Jason and the Argonauts.
name: Aries

mythology: The charioteer; in Greek mythology, Erichthonius, son of Vulcan, the first person to attach four horses to a chariot.
name: Auriga

mythology: The herdsman; in Greek mythology, Arcas, son of Zeus by Callisto.
name: Bootes

mythology: The chisel; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Caelum

mythology: The giraffe; a large but faint northern constellation introduced by Plancius in 1612.
name: Camelopardalis

mythology: The crab; in Greek mythology, a crab which bit Hercules's foot.
name: Cancer

mythology: The hunting dogs; introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, and said to be held by the herdsman Bootes.
name: Canes Venatici

mythology: The greater dog; in Greek mythology, a hunting dog belonging to Orion, depicted pursuing the hare Lepus.
name: Canis Major

mythology: The lesser dog; in Greek mythology, a hunting dog belonging to Orion, depicted pursuing the hare Lepus.
name: Canis Minor

mythology: The sea goat; associated with Pan in Greek mythology, god of the countryside.
name: Capricornus

mythology: The keel; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.
name: Carina

mythology: Queen Cassiopeia; in Greek mythology, wife of Cepheus and mother of Andromeda.
name: Cassiopeia

mythology: The Centaur: half man and half horse; in Greek mythology, the wise centaur Chiron.
name: Centaurus

mythology: King Cepheus of Ethiopeia; in Greek mythology, the king of Ethiopia, descended from Zeus and Io.
name: Cepheus

mythology: The sea monster, which in Greek mythology attacked Cepheus's territory and Andromeda, but which was slain by Perseus.
name: Cetus

mythology: The chameleon; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Chamaeleon

mythology: The pair of dividing compasses; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Circinus

mythology: The dove; introduced by Plancius in 1592. In Biblical history, said to be the dove of Noah.
name: Columba

mythology: The hair of Queen Berenice of Egypt; introduced as a constellation by Vopel in 1536.
name: Coma Berenices

mythology: The southern crown, lying at the feet of Sagittarius, and known to the Greeks as a wreath.
name: Corona Australis

mythology: The northern crown; in Greek mythology, worn by the Princess Ariadne on her wedding day.
name: Corona Borealis

mythology: The crow; in Greek mythology, sent by Apollo in search of water.
name: Corvus

mythology: The cup; in Greek mythology, clutched by the crow Crater in its search for water.
name: Crater

mythology: The southern cross; introduced as a constellation by Plancius in 1598.
name: Crux

mythology: The swan; in Greek mythology, Zeus in disguise.
name: Cygnus

mythology: The dolphin; in Greek mythology, the messenger of Poseidon.
name: Delphinus

mythology: The goldfish; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Dorado

mythology: The dragon; in Greek mythology, Ladon, guard of the tree on which golden apples grew, slain by Hercules.
name: Draco

mythology: The little horse; a tiny yet ancient constellation with no mythological association.
name: Equuleus

mythology: The mythical river Eridanus; associated variously with the Nile or Po.
name: Eridanus

mythology: The furnace; originally a chemist's distillation furnace, introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Fornax

mythology: The mythical twins Castor and Pollux.
name: Gemini

mythology: The crane; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Grus

mythology: Hercules; a large yet dark constellation representing the greatest hero of Greek mythology.
name: Hercules

mythology: The pendulum clock; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Horologium

mythology: The multi-headed water snake, slain by Hercules in Greek mythology.
name: Hydra

mythology: The lesser water snake; introduced as a constellation by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Hydrus

mythology: The Indian; introduced as a constellation by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Indus

mythology: The lizard; introduced as a constellation by Johannes Hevelius in 1690.
name: Lacerta

mythology: The lion of Nemea; in Greek mythology, a monster slain by Hercules.
name: Leo

mythology: The lion cub; introduced as a constellation by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.
name: Leo Minor

mythology: The hare; often depicted being chased by Orion and his two dogs.
name: Lepus

mythology: The balance; a zodiacal constellation introduced by the Romans.
name: Libra

mythology: The wolf; an ancient constellation, but without mythological association.
name: Lupus

mythology: The lynx; a faint constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.
name: Lynx

mythology: The lyre; often said to be played by Orpheus, the greatest musician of his age.
name: Lyra

mythology: Table Mountain, South Africa; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, celebrating his southern-hemisphere observing site.
name: Mensa

mythology: The microscope; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Microscopium

mythology: The unicorn; a constellation introduced by Plancius in 1612.
name: Monoceros

mythology: The fly; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Musca

mythology: The set square; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Norma

mythology: The octant, a navigational instrument invented in the 1730s. A modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Octans

mythology: The serpent bearer; in Greek mythology, Asclepius, the god of medicine, depicted in the sky holding the snake Serpens.
name: Ophiuchus

mythology: The hunter; associated in Greek mythology with a son of Poseidon, but associated by the Sumerians with their great hero Gilgamesh.
name: Orion

mythology: The peacock; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Pavo

mythology: The winged horse; in Greek mythology, used by Zeus to carry thunder and lightning.
name: Pegasus

mythology: Perseus; in Greek mythology, the husband of Andromeda, also known for slaying Medusa the Gorgon.
name: Perseus

mythology: The phoenix; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Phoenix

mythology: The painter's easel; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Pictor

mythology: Two fishes, swimming in opposite directions with their tails connected by a cord.
name: Pisces

mythology: The southern fish; the parent of the two fish depicted by Pisces.
name: Piscis Austrinus

mythology: The poop deck of the Argo Navis; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.
name: Puppis

mythology: The compass; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Pyxis

mythology: The net; a southern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756, commemorating the cross-hair in his telescope.
name: Reticulum

mythology: The arrow; in Greek mythology, perhaps the arrow that Apollo used to kill the Cyclopes.
name: Sagitta

mythology: The archer; usually drawn as a centaur – half man, half horse
name: Sagittarius

mythology: The scorpion; said to have stung the hunter Orion to death in Greek mythology.
name: Scorpius

mythology: The sculptor – originally, the sculptor's studio; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Sculptor

mythology: The shield; a constellation honouring King John III Sobieski of Poland – the only politically inspired constellation still in use.
name: Scutum

mythology: The serpent's head; held by Ophiuchus and part of the same constellation as Serpens Cauda.
name: Serpens Caput

mythology: The serpent's tail; held by Ophiuchus and part of the same constellation as Serpens Caput.
name: Serpens Cauda

mythology: The sextant; a constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, celebrating an instrument used to measure star positions.
name: Sextans

mythology: The bull; said by the Sumerians to be charging at Orion the hunter, but in Greek mythology said to be Zeus in disguise.
name: Taurus

mythology: The telescope; a modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in 1756.
name: Telescopium

mythology: The triangle; appearing similar to a capital delta in the Greek alphabet.
name: Triangulum

mythology: The southern triangle; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Triangulum Australe

mythology: The toucan; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598.
name: Tucana

mythology: The great bear, also known as the Big Dipper or the Plough. In Greek mythology, Callisto, lover of Zeus.
name: Ursa Major

mythology: The lesser bear; in Greek mythology, one of the nymphs that nursed Zeus as an infant.
name: Ursa Minor

mythology: The sail; a sub-division of the ancient constellation Argo – in Greek mythology, the ship of the Argonauts.
name: Vela

mythology: The virgin; in Greek mythology, the goddess of justice.
name: Virgo

mythology: The flying fish; a constellation introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in 1598, celebrating the family Exocoetidae.
name: Volans

mythology: The fox; a constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687.
name: Vulpecula
